definition: to speak forcibly out of a sense of righteousness (idiom)
justice/righteousness/meaning/foster (father etc)/adopted/artificial (tooth, limb etc)/relationship/friendship
surname Yi/(Tw) abbr. for 義大利|义大利[Yi4 da4 li4], Italy
first month of the lunar year
straight/upright/proper/main/principal/to correct/to rectify/exactly/just (at that time)/right (in that place)/(math.) positive
old variant of 辭|辞[ci2]

sentences.english: Such the word "revolution" sounded a bit horrible for me, but on his side it meant justice.
sentences.chinese: 这种词在我听来带点儿恐怖，在他却是义正辞严。

sentences.english: He refused the bribe with the force of justice.
sentences.chinese: 他义正辞严地拒绝了别人送他的贿赂。

definition: stern words
devotion to righteousness that inspires reverence (idiom)
to speak forcefully and with justice (idiom); to argue with the courage of one's convictions
to speak forcefully and with justice (idiom); to argue with the courage of one's convictions/also written 振振有詞|振振有词
forceful (criticism etc)/to use strong words
righteous indignation fills one's breast (idiom); to feel indignant at injustice
in the right and self-confident (idiom); bold and confident with justice on one's side/to have the courage of one's convictions/just and forceful
to twist words and force logic (idiom)/sophistry/loud rhetoric making up for fallacious argument/shoving false arguments down people's throats
impassioned/vehement
to criticize harshly/to denounce/to attack viciously
lit. if thrown on the floor, it will make a sound (idiom)/fig. (of one's words) powerful and resonating/to have substance
solemn in countenance (idiom); strict and unsmiling
faulty argument and poor rhetoric (idiom); unable to put forward any convincing arguments/without a leg to stand on
sternly/solemn
lit. to slap the table and stand up (idiom); fig. at the end of one's tether/unable to take it any more
according to reason/in principle
